Christy, James  Everett

      James Everett Maywood Christy, 52, of Graysville, died at 6:15 a.m. May 7, 1985, in Marietta Memorial Hospital, following a lengthy illness.  Hew as born Dec. 27, 1932 in Monroe County, a ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'>Christy, James Everett

James Everett Maywood Christy, 52, of Graysville, died at 6:15 a.m. May 7, 1985, in Marietta Memorial Hospital, following a lengthy illness. Hew as born Dec. 27, 1932 in Monroe County, a >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 son of the late Clarence Maywood Christy and Edna Smith Christy, who survives at Woodsfield.

     Mr. Christy was a member of Graysville Church of Christ, presently vice president of the Monroe County Board of Education and had served on boards of education for 25 years.  He was a member ======= "Times New Roman";mso-fareast-language:JA'> Mr. Christy was a member of Graysville Church of Christ, presently vice president of the Monroe County Board of Education and had served on boards of education for 25 years. He was a member >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 of the Stafford Lodge 300, F&A.M.; was employed at Ormet Corporation, Hannibal; member of Skyvue Boosters Club and past president; an Army veteran serving during the Korean conflict.

     On June 7, 1952, he married Frances Schmidt who survives at Graysville.  Also surviving are four ======= "Times New Roman";mso-fareast-language:JA'> On June 7, 1952, he married Frances Schmidt who survives at Graysville. Also surviving are four >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 sons, Gregory J. of Lewisville Mitchell of Jerusalem, Vaughn L. of the home; Scott A. of the home; three grandchildren; three sisters, Mrs. Harold (Dorothy) Harmon of Bridgeport; Mrs. Erma Dye of Shadyside; Mrs. Fred (Cynthia) Regger of Lancaster; one brother, Eldon of Route 1, Graysville.

      He was preceded in death by one brother and one sister.

      Friends were received at the Watters Funeral Home May 8 where services ere held May 9 with Minister Delbert Westbrook officiating.  Burial in Oaklawn Cemetery, Woodsfield

Christy, Mitchell Drew "Mitch"
Source--Monroe County Beacon      Woodsfield, Ohio
======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> Woodsfield, Ohio >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711
Published--November 16, 2004
            Mitchell Drew  "Mitch" Christy, 44, 33287 Devoe Ridge Road, Lewisville, died November 6, 2004, near Lewisville, following injuries received in an automobile accident. He was born at Marietta,  on September 25, 1960, a son ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> Mitchell Drew "Mitch" Christy, 44, 33287 Devoe Ridge Road, Lewisville, died November 6, 2004, near Lewisville, following injuries received in an automobile accident. He was born at Marietta, on September 25, 1960, a son >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 of Frances Schmidt Christy Hixon, of Lake Placid, Florida and the late James E. Christy.
He was a 1978 graduate of Skyvue High School and Swiss Hills Vocational School. He was a maintenance worker at Ormet Corporation, Hannibal. He was a member of Stafford Lodge # 300, F & A.M., Stafford, and was a member of the Steelworkers Union # 5724, Clarington.
Surviving in addition to his mother, are his wife, Becki Workman Christy, of the home; step-father, Donald Hixon, of Lake Placid, Florida; two sons, Tyler Christy , Travis Christy, of the home; daughter, Courtney Sutton, of Columbus; one step-son, Brad Workman, of the home; three brothers, Gregory James (Carol) Christy, of Lewisville, Vaughn L. (Pam) Christy, of Woodsfield, Scott A. (Cathy) Christy, of Delaware, Ohio; one uncle and several aunts; several nieces, nephews and cousins.
Friends were received at Watters Funeral Home, Woodsfield, November 11, where funeral service will be held November 12, with Reverend Richard Wilson officiating. Burial followed in Oaklawn Cemetery, Woodsfield.
Masonic services were held November 11 at the funeral home.

                        ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 The single ring ceremony was performed on Saturday afternoon, June twenty-fifth, at two-fifteen by the groom's
                        ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 uncle, Evangelist Charles Hendershot. The ceremony took place at the home of Evangelist Hendershot in Akron.

She carried out the old tradition of something old, new, borrowed and blue with a penny in her shoe. She carried a bridal bouquet of roses.

Christy, Scott Andrew and Cathy Elaine Wilson
Source--Monroe County Beacon    Woodsfield, Ohio
======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> Woodsfield, Ohio >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711
Published--September 16, 1999
            Reverend and Mrs. Richard Wilson of Jerusalem, proudly announce the engagement and approaching marriage of their daughter, Cathy Elaine to Scott  Andrew ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> Reverend and Mrs. Richard Wilson of Jerusalem, proudly announce the engagement and approaching marriage of their daughter, Cathy Elaine to Scott Andrew >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Christy, son of Mrs. Frances Hixon, formerly of Graysville, and the late James Christy.
The bride-to-be is a graduate of Beallsville High School and received a bachelor's degree in community service-child development / family studies from Ohio University and a master's degree in human ecology from The Ohio State University. She is an educational consultant for the Ohio Department of Education.
Her fiance is a graduate of Skyvue High School and received a bachelor's degree in civil engineering from The Ohio State University. He is project engineer with Turner Construction.
The wedding will take place October 9 at Church of the Master United Methodist Church, in Westerville.

Mrs. Ruth Parr, of New Matamoras, >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 announces the marriage of their daughter, Jean Parr Church to Mr. Russell Nicewander of Massillon. The candlelight ceremony was performed at six o'clock, Friday, February twenty-fifth, ay Saint John's Evangelical Church in Massillon. The Reverend Otto Gerber was the officiating minister.
                  ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 The bride wore a dark green suit with black accessories and a corsage of yellow rosebuds. Immediate families and close friends of the couple were in attendance.

                  The couple is residing at Massillon.
                  ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> The couple is residing at Massillon.
>>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 The bride's mother, Mrs. Ruth Parr, of New Matamoras gave a shower for the bride on March 3rd at her home, on Grandview Avenue. Invitations were extended to Mrs.Harley Marsh, Mrs. Gene Cochran, Mrs. Grace Heddleston, Mrs. Donald Petty, Mrs. Homer Smith, Mrs, Helen Taylor, Mrs. George Burbacher, Miss Mary Baker, Mrs. Oce Baker, Mrs. Roscoe Cunningham and Mrs. Lena May.

Mr. Nicewander is a graduate of Massillon High School and is employed with Republic Steel of Massillon.
 
Cieszeski, Frances (nee Harman)
Source--Monroe County Beacon      Woodsfield, Ohio
======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> Woodsfield, Ohio >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711
Published--Thursday, October 21, 2004
    Cieszeski, ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> Cieszeski, >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Frances (nee-Harman), 81, of Fulton, New York, died October 14, 2004,at A.L. Memorial Hospital. She was born in Graysville, a daughter of the late Greal and Mabel Harman and has been a longtime resident of Fulton.
    She was a ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> She was a >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 graduate of Graysville High School in 1937. She was a communicant of The First United Church of Fulton, formerly The First Baptist Church. She was a loving wife, mother , grandmother, and great-grandmother. She was a 4-H leader in Monroe County,a
den mother for Cub Scouts, a religious education teacher at First Baptist Church and a charter member of The Women of Rotary, and a member of The Women's Hospital Auxilliary.
   Surviving are ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> Surviving are >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 her husband of 61 years, Charles Cieszeski of Fulton; daughter, Connie(Barry)Thompkins; a son, Charles H. Cieszeski, all of Fulton; brother, Steward Harman, of Columbus; Aunt Elifrede Christy of Richwood; three grandchildren, Karey (William) Pine, Amy (Jonathon) Johnston, Andrew O'B Cieszeski; four great-grandchildren, Olivia Pine, Audrey, Tavish and Samuel Johnston; several nieces and nephews.
   In addition to her parents, she was preceded in death by a brother, Richard Harman.
   Friends ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> In addition to her parents, she was preceded in death by a brother, Richard Harman.
Friends >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 received October 19, at Fulton Alliance Church, Fulton. Funeral services and burial
were private.
   Memorial ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> Memorial >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 contributions may be made th Graysville High School Alumni Association, Graysville,
Ohio 45734 or The First United Church of Fulton,  33 South 3rd Street, Fulton, New York 13069.
   Sugar Funeral Home, Incorporated, Fulton, was in charge of the arrangements.

Published--February   ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> Saint Clairsville, Ohio
Published--February >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 14, 2005
Clark , Frederick Nelson , age 65, of Bellaire, Ohio, died Saturday, February 12, 2005 at his home. He was born February 4, 1940 at Stewartsville, Ohio, son of the late Richard Kenneth Clark and Bessie Loraine Simmons Clark. Fred was a retired employee from HLC Trucking in Powhatan Point, <<<<<<< HEAD Ohio.  He served in the United States Navy ======= Ohio. He served in the United States Navy >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 and was a member of the Eagles Aerie # 371, Federal Order of Eagles in Bellaire. In addition to his parents, Fred was preceded in death by a son, James Richard Clark in 1994 and a brother, Thomas Clark in 1996. Surviving are his daughter, Susan Lynn Kienbaum of Spokane, Washington; three sons, Michael Allen Clark of Bellaire, Thomas Wayne Clark of Saint Clairsville and Glenn Charles Clark of Shadyside; a brother, Donald Dwayne Clark of Seven Hills, Ohio; 10 grandchildren; and a great grandchild. Family and friends will be received at Toothman Funeral Home in Saint Clairsville on Monday, February 14, 2005 from 12 noon until time of services at 2 p.m., with Reverend R. J. Clark <<<<<<< HEAD officiating.  Burial will follow at Rock ======= officiating. Burial will follow at Rock >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Hill Cemetery, Bellaire, Ohio. Memorial contributions may be made to the American Cancer Society, 3612 Maple Avenue, Zanesville, Ohio 43702 or online at www.cancer.org
 
Claus, Clemence G. [Source:Newspaper clipping of February 1919]
  Private ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> Private >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Clemence G. Claus was the son of Frederick and Caroline Haffner Claus of near Miltonsburg, Ohio. He was born there July 11, 1895 and was baptized and confirmed according to the rites of the Evangelical Church. He was selected for service in the United States Army on July 22, 1918. The many hardships of our soldier boys across the sea was also a portion of his experiences. Finally the Armistice was signed. Yet to some signing of the Armistice was not as assurance of the safe return of their loved one. On the fourth of February, 1919, the household of Mr. and Mrs. Fred Claus was shocked and grieved upon the receipt of a letter from Captain Spier containing the sad news that their boy whom they had all thought well and contented in Grancem had died four weeks before.
  Private ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> Private >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Clemence G. Claus left the world behind and entered into eternal rest on January 12, 1919. He had been suffering form meningitis. He had reached the tender age of 23 years, six months and one day old. The end came at Dernbach, Germany; where he was also laid to rest in the First Division cemetery. This however was to be his final resting place. The remains were removed from their first resting place and brought to his native country. On July 19, 1920, the body of the deceased arrived at Woodsfield, Ohio to be buried in the family lot in St. <<<<<<< HEAD Peters Evangelical cemetery at Miltonsburg, Ohio.
  The deceased ======= Peter s Evangelical cemetery at Miltonsburg, Ohio.
The deceased >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 patriot and loyal soldier leaves behind his father and mother, Mr. and Mrs. Fed Claus; three sisters; Mrs. Fred (Anna Catherina) Christman; Mrs. Herman (Minnie Caroline) Egger; and Mrs. Elmer (Clara Louisa) Christman; four brothers, Edwin Fredrick Claus and Benjamin Henry Claus residing in Iowa; Leroy Alfred Claus and Gilbert John Claus are living at the home of their parents.
  The funeral ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> The funeral >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 took place Sunday July 25, 1920. Services in the Church began at 2 p.m. The local preacher delivered the sermon. The American Legion was present and took over the services at the grave under Captain Mooney and Chaplain Charles Jones. The bugler was Robert Diehl. The pallbearers were ex-soldiers Chester Reller, Grover Knapp, Joseph Reight, Bernard Kress, and Nicholas Reimenschneider.
  Reverend ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> Reverend >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Muecke then officiated in laying the body in its final resting place in the Evangelical Miltonsburg cemetery.

Claus, Adolph H.
Died: May 2, 1929, residence: Miltonsburg
 
Claus, Alvin V.

July 28, 1954

IN THE SERVICE

  Pfc. Alvin V. Claus, son of Mr. and ======= JA'> Pfc. Alvin V. Claus, son of Mr. and >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Mrs. Gilbert Claus, of Lewisville, Route 1, is stationed at Metz, France. On Memorial Day, French and American troops participated in ceremonies held at the Meuse-Argonne American Cemetery, Pfc. Claus representing the 26th Q. M. Refrigeration Platoon. Each company of the Metz Q. M. Deport participated. Lt. Gen. Charles L. Bolte, USAREUR Commander-in-Chief, gave the address to over 1000 French and American officials, dignitaries and guest before the great cemetery chapel over looking 14,244 American graves of two World Wars. The 118 Army Band played the Marseillaise and the Star Spangled Banner.

   'Alvin's address is Pfc. Alvin V. ======= JA'> 'Alvin's address is Pfc. Alvin V. >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Claus, U. S. 52-176-69, 26th Q. M. Refrigeration Platoon, APO 216, Care Postmaster, New York, New York.

 
Claus, Bertha Reich and Mr. John J. Andrews      X
            Mrs. Bertha Claus Reich, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Charles Claus, and J. J. Andrews, son of the late W. H. Andrews, were united in marriage on Sunday evening, May 11, 1952, at the home of the bride on South Sycamore Street.             Minister J. V. A. Traylor read the marriage vows at six oclock in the presence of the couples children and grandchildren.
            Attending ======= style='mso-tab-count:1'> X
Mrs. Bertha Claus Reich, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Charles Claus, and J. J. Andrews, son of the late W. H. Andrews, were united in marriage on Sunday evening, May 11, 1952, at the home of the bride on South Sycamore Street. Minister J. V. A. Traylor read the marriage vows at six o clock in the presence of the couple s children and grandchildren.
Attending >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 the ceremony were Mr. and Mrs. Vernon Reich and family, of Jerusalem, Ohio; Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Reich and family, of Miltonsburg, Ohio; Mr. and Mrs. G. W. Andrews and family of Barnesville, Ohio.
Source: The Monroe County Beacon, Woodsfield, Ohio, May 1952
Provided by Wilda Heft Bartenschlag

Claus, Elizabeth (nee Ackerman)            X
  Elizabeth ======= style='mso-tab-count:1'> X
Elizabeth >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Claus, nee Ackerman, was born February 7, 1819, in Hannasfield, Spanixburg, Hastelcastel, Germany. In 1843, in Germany, she united in marriage to Henry Claus, Sr., and they shared each other=s joys and sorrows for fifty-eight years. In the year 1847 they came to America and made their home near Monroefield, Ohio and became members of the Miltonsburg Evangelical Church, Miltonsburg, Ohio. They had two sons born in Germany - Justus and ( Casper, who died while crossing the ocean.) The other children (born here) were Elizabeth, Henry, Adolph, and Fredrick. She took sick about the 24th day of June, and died on Sunday morning, July 7, 1901. She leaves her husband, five children, 34 grandchildren, and eleven great-grandchildren. She was a sister to Conrad Ackerman. She reached the age of 82 years and 5 months. Her burial was made in the Miltonsburg cemetery, Miltonsburg, Ohio.
Source: The Spirit of Democracy, Woodsfield, Ohio, July 1901

Claus, Freda

November 5, 1986

The Monroe County Beacon, Woodsfield, Ohio

Freda L. Claus, nee Hossman

     Freda L. (Hossman) Claus, 87, died Oct. 24, at Akron City Hospital.  Mrs. Claus was born in Malaga, but lived most her life in Akron.  During the past 35 years, she lived in Melbourne, FL part of the year.

     ======= "Times New Roman";mso-fareast-language:JA'> Freda L. (Hossman) Claus, 87, died Oct. 24, at Akron City Hospital. Mrs. Claus was born in Malaga, but lived most her life in Akron. During the past 35 years, she lived in Melbourne, FL part of the year.

>>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 She was preceded in death by her husband, Walter C. Claus, eight brothers and one sister and one grandson.

     ======= "Times New Roman";mso-fareast-language:JA'> >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 She is survived by two daughters, Mrs. C. Edward (Evelyn) Reed of Akron, Mrs. Grace Jones of Atwater; one son, Wilbert of Lewisville; eight grandsons and 12 great-grandchildren.

     ======= "Times New Roman";mso-fareast-language:JA'> >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Services were held Oct. 27 at 2:30 p.m. from Hopkins Lawyer Funeral Home, Akron. Burial in Hillside Memorial Park.

 

September 23, 1989

BIRTHDAY

Gilbert Claus

Source: Monroe County Beacon

 

     On September 3 friends and ======= JA'> On September 3 friends and >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 relatives gathered at the Americare Nursing Home in honor Gilbert Claus on his 85th birthday, which was September 6. Also celebrating birthdays were two of grandchildren, Peggy Carpenter and David Wilhelm and his nephew, Raymond Christman.

     Those present were his three ======= JA'> Those present were his three >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 children along with two grandchildren, two great grandchildren, several relatives and friends.

     In attendance were: Raymond and ======= JA'> In attendance were: Raymond and >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Lela Christman of Barnesville; Alvin and Clara Claus of Wooster; Carl and Peggy Carpenter of Marietta; Vivian, Pauline and Thelma Matz of Woodsfield; Roscoe and Virginia Wilhelm; David, Sonja, Ben and Rachel Wilhelm; Beryl and Wilbert Claus; George and Laura Kahrig; Alfred and Gertrude Kahrig; Edward and Beulah Ackerman of Lewisville; Frances Thomas, along with Gilbert and wife Esther Claus of the Americare Home.

 

 
Claus, Gilbert J.
Source:  The Monroe County Beacon, Woodsfield, Ohio, March 1995
  Gilbert J. ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'>Source: The Monroe County Beacon, Woodsfield, Ohio, March 1995
Gilbert J. >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Claus, 90, of Route 2, Lewisville, Ohio, died March 21, 1995 at the Woodsfield Nursing and Rehabilitation Center. He was born September 6, 1904 in Monroe County, Ohio, a son of the late Fred Claus and Caroline Haffner Claus.
  He was a retired farmer. He was a member of the Trinity United Church of Christ, Lewisville and a member of the Trinity Mens Brotherhood.
  Surviving are ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> He was a retired farmer. He was a member of the Trinity United Church of Christ, Lewisville and a member of the Trinity Men s Brotherhood.
Surviving are >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 one son, Alvin Claus, Wooster, Ohio; two daughters, Mrs. Roscoe (Virginia) Wilhelm, Lewisville and Mrs. William (Vivian) Paulus, Woodsfield; seven grandchildren and 11 great-grandchildren.
  He was ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> He was >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 preceded in by his wife, Esther Christman Claus, April 28, 1994, also three sisters and five brothers.
  Friends were received March 24 at the Bauer-Turner Funeral Home, Woodsfield, where services were held March 25 with the Reverend Richard Wilson officiating. Interment in the St. Johns Cemetery (Middle Church), near Lewisville.

Claus, Grace Anna, nee Hayes
Source--News Clipping
Published-April 1984
 
======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711
Claus, Grace A., 66, a resident of Barnesville, died April 30 in Barnesville Hospital. She was born September 10, 1918 in Monroe County, a daughter of the late Daniel and Carrie Bell Hutchinson Hayes.
She was a Protestant and a member of the Order of Eastern Star Number 276, Somerton Chapter and Ladies' of The Moose.
She was preceded in death by a daughter, three brothers and a sister.
Surviving are her husband, Lewis Wesley Claus; two daughters, Mrs. Oscar (Darlene) Smith of Barstow, California, and Mrs. Byron (Myra) Morris of Akron; a step-daughter, Mrs. Floyd (Linda) Crawford of Malaga, three sisters, Mrs. Susie Butler, Mrs. Edna Truax, both of Caldwell, and Mrs. Nellie Keylor of Summerfield; a brother, David Hayes of Quaker City; five grandchildren.
Services were held at the Campbell-Plumly Funeral Home, Barnesville, Saturday with the Reverend James Porter officiating. Burial in Oaklawn Cemetery, Woodsfield.
 
CARD OF THANKS--GRACE CLAUS     We, the family of Grace Claus, would like ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'>
CARD OF THANKS--GRACE CLAUS We, the family of Grace Claus, would like >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 to express our sincere thanks and appreciation to the following: the Barnesville E-Squad, Barnesville Emergency Room, Emergency Doctors and Nurses who helped with our Mom and Dad.
We can never express our gratitude to our relatives, friends and neighbors for their prayers, phone calls, visits, cards, food, and beautiful flowers.
A special thanks to Reverend Thomas, Reverend Truax, and Reverend Densmore for their comforting words in the most difficult time, to the Campbell-Plumly Funeral Home, Somerton Eastern Stars Number 276, Auxillary of the Eagles Number 937.

Claus, Harry E. Claus
 
July 7, 1912
 
Feb 22, 1999
 
Jerusalem
 
Claus, Henry, <<<<<<< HEAD Sr.           X
               On Friday, October 14, 1904, a ======= Sr. X
On Friday, October 14, 1904, a >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 large assembly met at Miltonsburg, Ohio to pay the last respects to Henry Claus, Sr., who on that day was committed to the earth. Mr. Claus was born February 15, 1818, in Hessia, the son of Johannes (John) and Katharina KUHLMAN Claus. On May 25, 1843, in Germany, he entered the state of matrimony with Elizabeth Ackerman, the daughter of Adam Ackerman and Katharina KAUL Ackerman from Herlefeld, Germany. Elizabeth was born February 7, 1819, in Hannasfield, Spanixburg, Hastelcastel, Germany and died July 7, 1901. In 1847, immigrated to America, and settled in Miltonsburg, Monroe County, Ohio. The union was blessed with six children, five sons and one daughter. One son, Casper Claus died at sea on the way to America. Four sons, Adolph, Justice, Frederick, and Henry, and one daughter, Mrs. Andrew (Elizabeth) REICH, thirty-five grandchildren and twenty-one great-grandchildren mourn the loss of the departed. Father Claus had suffered for a Long time and was called to his eternal rest on Wednesday, October 12th., age 86 years, 7 months and 27 days. The interment took place on Friday, October 14 in the Miltonsburg cemetery, Miltonsburg, Ohio, with the Reverend F. A. MEUSCH having charge of the services. His wife, Elizabeth is buried there also. Mr. Claus was the oldest member of the Miltonsburg Evangelical Church, and was connected with that Church ever since his coming to <<<<<<< HEAD this country.  
Source:    The Spirit of Democracy, Woodsfield, Ohio, ======= this country.
Source: The Spirit of Democracy, Woodsfield, Ohio, >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Thurs., November 10, 1904
Collection of Beryl Christman Claus
 
 
 
Claus, Henry, II
               Henry Claus, II was born July 18, ======= style='mso-tab-count:1'> Henry Claus, II was born July 18, >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 1850, near Miltonsburg, Ohio, the son of Heinrich and Elisabeth Claus. He was taught to love his Savior in early youth and was confirmed at the age of 14. On January 26th, 1875, he was united in marriage to Miss Margaret Muller, which union was blessed with six children - - two sons and four daughters, of whom one son died in infancy.
               Mr. Claus was an Earnest and ======= style='mso-tab-count:1'> Mr. Claus was an Earnest and >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 faithful member of his church. He also endeavored to keep up the German language in his home, giving his parents the pleasure of hearing their grandchildren converse in their native tongue.
               During the recent conference of ======= style='mso-tab-count:1'> During the recent conference of >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 pastors in his church he and his wife took active interest in the matter and lent a willing and helping had to the work. On Sunday morning Mr. Claus, with wife and son, journeyed to the church where he found all of his daughters with their families assembled. After greeting them, services were taken during which he, joined by his wife, took communion with the congregation. At the conclusion of the services the entire family assembled on the lawn, partaking of the refreshments which they had provided for in the morning. It was a happy family reunion and everyone felt the joy of being once more united. They did not know that it was to be the last time in this world.
               During the afternoon services he, ======= style='mso-tab-count:1'> During the afternoon services he, >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 with a number of others, every place in the church being filled, remained at the entrance, an attentive listener to the word of God which was being proclaimed from the pulpit. Without wArning or any alarming symptoms the Lord suddenly called him to his heavenly home. He expired in the parsonage where friends had taken him almost instantly, without regaining his conscience. A stroke of paralysis had stopped the beating of his heart. Mr. Claus died May 20, 1906, at an age of 55 years, 10 months, and 2 days. His remains were interred in the cemetery of the Evangelical Church of Miltonsburg, Ohio, his pastor, Rev. F. A. MEUSCH, conducting the services and the choir rendering appropriate music.
               That Mr. Claus was highly ======= style='mso-tab-count:1'> That Mr. Claus was highly >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 respected and beloved in his community was proven by the large attendance at his funeral, 67 wagons following the remains from his residence, which were joined by a large number before the cemetery was reached.
               Mr. Claus leaves his wife, five children, three brothers, one sister and six grandchildren, besides an unlimited number of friends to mourn his early departure. May we all meet him in heaven.                                                A BRothER
Source:    The Spirit of Democracy, Woodsfield, Ohio, ======= style='mso-tab-count:1'> Mr. Claus leaves his wife, five children, three brothers, one sister and six grandchildren, besides an unlimited number of friends to mourn his early departure. May we all meet him in heaven. A BRothER
Source: The Spirit of Democracy, Woodsfield, Ohio, >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Thursday, June 7, 1906
Collection of Gertrude Christman Kahrig
 
 
Henry Philip Claus
Source:Newspaper clipping, Issue: 1944
  Henry Philip ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> Henry Philip >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Claus, departed this life Monday, March 20, 1944, at his home near Middle Church at the age of 73 years, 10 months, and 20 days. Although his was sudden, he had been in failing health since undergoing operation a year ago.
  He was born May 1, 1870, in Malaga Township, and was the son of the late Justus and Carolina Schmidt Claus. He was confirmed at the St. Johns Evangelical and ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> He was born May 1, 1870, in Malaga Township, and was the son of the late Justus and Carolina Schmidt Claus. He was confirmed at the St. John s Evangelical and >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Reformed Church in Summit township where he remained a faithful member until his . He was united in marriage on January 30, 1894, with Miss Minnie Brubach. He spent his entire life in this community, where he had made a host of lifeLong friends, who in addition to his family and relatives will mourn his passing.
  Surviving Mrs. ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> Surviving Mrs. >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Claus are his wife, three sons: Everett Claus, of Lewisville; Walter Claus, of Akron; Emil Claus, of Bucyrus; one daughter, Mrs. Hulda McDonough, of Akron; eleven grandchildren, two great grandchildren, two sisters; Mrs. Ann Friday, of Columbus; Mrs. Elizabeth Wilhelm, of Parkersburg, W. Va., and three brothers: Herman Claus and Clarence Claus, of Hornick, Iowa, and Edward Claus, of Pittsburgh, Pa. Two sisters, Mrs. Louise Scheurr, of Pittsburg, Pa., and Mrs. Clara Theiss, of Lower Salem, Ohio, and one brother, Jacob Claus, of Hornick, Iowa, preceded him in .
  Just recently ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> Just recently >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Mr. and Mrs. Claus together with the family observed their golden wedding anniversary.

Thomas, Hilma Morn, nee Claus
Source--Monroe County Beacon     Woodsfield, Ohio
======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> Woodsfield, Ohio >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711
Published--Thursday, October 7, 2004
    Thomas, ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> Thomas, >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Hilma Morn, 96, of Marietta, formerly of Lower Salem, died September 26, 2004, at
Harmar Place in Marietta. She was born March 18, 1908 in Lower Salem, to the late Lewis and Clara F. Claus Theiss.
    She was a ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> She was a >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 1926 graduate of Salem-Liberty High School. She was a member of the Warner United Church of Christ, the Warner Women's Quilting Group, and a 54 year member of Elk Township Grange #2732. She had remained on the family farm until 1998 when she went to live                                                                  at The Jaycee Estates in Marietta. Hilma enjoyed gardening and quilting.
    Surviving are three sons, Vernon (Shirley) Thomas, of Lower Salem,  Vaughn (Alice) Thomas, of Mount Vernon,  John (Elaine) Thomas, Marietta; two ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> at The Jaycee Estates in Marietta. Hilma enjoyed gardening and quilting.

Thomas, Carol (Larry) Groves, Roger (Nancy) Thomas, Vicki (Frank) Cowans, Lisa (Russ) Hughes, Mark (Heather) Thomas, Rodney (Renee) Skoglund, Ryan (Karen) Skoglund, Debra (Ron) Curfman, John Thomas II, Diane (Todd) Weber, Darlene (Jeff) Swartz, Deanne Hesson and Douglas Hesson; 32 great grandchildren; four great-great grandchildren; brother-in-law Roy Baker, <<<<<<< HEAD of  The Inn at Marietta; several nieces and nephews.

Mrs. Laura Claus

Claus, Lewis

Lewis Claus, 75

     Lewis Claus, 75, 60340 Somerton Highway, Barnesville died July 1, 1987, in Barnesville Hospital.  He was born Sept. 28, 1911 at Miltonsburg, son of the late William and Laura Neisz Claus.

      ======= "Times New Roman";mso-fareast-language:JA'> Lewis Claus, 75, 60340 Somerton Highway, Barnesville died July 1, 1987, in Barnesville Hospital. He was born Sept. 28, 1911 at Miltonsburg, son of the late William and Laura Neisz Claus.

>>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 He was a retired employee of Consolidated Aluminum Corp., Clarington, and a member of Moose Lodge #1304, Eagles, VFW, all at Barnesville, and Masonic Lodge #354 at Somerton.

     ======= "Times New Roman";mso-fareast-language:JA'> >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 He was preceded in death by his wives, Leora Claus and Grace Claus; two brothers, Lawrence and Paul Claus; a sister, Mildred.

     ======= "Times New Roman";mso-fareast-language:JA'> >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Surviving are three daughters, Mrs. Floyd (Linda) Crawford of Reynoldsburg, Mrs. Byron (Myra) Morris of Akron, and Mrs. Oscar (Darlene) Smith of Barnesville; a sister, Mrs. Earl (Leona) Skaggs of Bethesda; five grandchildren; two great-grandchildren.

     ======= "Times New Roman";mso-fareast-language:JA'> >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Friends were received at the Campbell-Plumly Funeral Home, Barnesville, where services were held Friday. Burial following in Oaklawn Cemetery, Woodsfield.

 

 
Claus, Loren and Richard Fankhauser

   Claus,Loren ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> Claus,Loren >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 and Richard Fankhauser, cousins are the sons of Mr. and Mrs. Emil Claus

Claus, Lydia L.
Born: September 25, 1897, died: March 9, 1919
Lydia L. Claus, (nee Kilburn) [Source: Newspaper clipping March 1919]
  Lydia Louise ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> Lydia Louise >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Claus, wife of Walter Charles Claus, died Sunday, March 9, 1919,age 21 years, 5 months and 12 days, after an illness of a few days of the influenza. She bore her sickness and affliction without murmur or complaint and sweetly fell asleep to wake in her blest home. She was born September 25, 1897, the daughter of Gustav F. Kilburn and Mary Kahrig. On April 9, 1911, she was confirmed at the <<<<<<< HEAD St. Johns Evangelical Church. She was a member of the Sunday School all the ======= St. John s Evangelical Church. She was a member of the Sunday School all the >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 days of her life. On October 31, 1916, she was united in marriage to Walter C. Claus. Short was the duration of the happy union. Like a thief of the night the news came from the clear sky of her . She leaves to mourn her , husband, Walter C. Claus; one son, Wilbert Walter Claus, aged two years;, one daughter, Grace Lydia Claus, aged 11 hours; father and mother, Mr. and Mrs. Gus Kilburn; 2 sisters, Estella Kilburn and Sylvia Kilburn, and 2 brothers, Freeman Kilburn and William Kilburn, besides the many friends who love her. She will be missed by us and all who knew her because she was so kind and pleasant to everyone and the work that she has done will bring her memory back to us. She was laid to <<<<<<< HEAD rest in St. Johns Middle Church cemetery, near Lewisville, Ohio with the ======= rest in St. John s Middle Church cemetery, near Lewisville, Ohio with the >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Reverend Meisenheimer officiating.
 
 
Claus, Margaret Claus nee Mueller/Miller    
 of Mrs. Claus
======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'>
of Mrs. Claus
>>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711
Died: November 13, 1929
Provided by Lena Kahrig Pettit, typed by Betty Lendon Matson
     The ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> The >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Miltonsburg community suffered a severe loss in the passing of Mrs. Margaret Claus, aged 76, at her home Friday near the noon hour, following a few days suffering of intestinal ailment. Hers was a life of real service to humanity, and her many kindly acts and deeds will find permanent lodgment in the memory of those befriended. Four children are bereft, Dora of the home; Mrs. Gertrude Weber and Mrs. Lewis Christman, of Lewisville; and Mrs. Louise Feldner, of Woodsfield; also two sisters, Mrs. Mary Lohri, of Trail Run; Mrs. Elizabeth Pfalzgraf, of Parkersburg, and one brother John in California.
     Funeral ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> Funeral >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 services in charge of her pastor, Rev. Chester Guam were held at Miltonsburg Evangelical Church on Sunday and were largely attended. We expect to publish obituary next week.
 
 
Margaret E. Claus (nee Hoff)
Source:Newspaper clipping of February 1941
 
  Life is a drop from the river,
  That rises in mist oer the lea,
  A moment in space of quiver,
  Then falls on the breast of the sea,
  It was- It is-now gone forever,
  Yet lives ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> Life is a drop from the river,
That rises in mist o er the lea,
A moment in space of quiver,
Then falls on the breast of the sea,
It was- It is-now gone forever,
Yet lives >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 through eternity.
 
 
  On Saturday morning, February 8, 1941, at six oclock the angel entered our home and called ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> On Saturday morning, February 8, 1941, at six o clock the angel entered our home and called >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 our dear and beloved wife and mother to her home to eternal rest at the age of 79 years, 9 months and 1 day.
  Margarite E. ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> Margarite E. >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Hoff Claus, the eldest daughter of Frederic and Margarite Zimmerle Hoff, was born on May 7, 1861, in Washington County, near Lebanon, Ohio.
  She was united ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> She was united >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 in marriage with Charles Claus, on June 14, 1883, who was her companion through 58 years of married life.
   She leaves to ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> She leaves to >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 mourn her sad departure her aged companion; two children, Oswald A. Claus, of Pittsburg; and Bertha Reich, of Miltonsburg, Ohio; the following grandchildren, Mrs. Charlotte Brown and Miss Mildred Claus of Longview, Texas; Arthur Reich, of Miltonsburg and Vernon Reich of Lewisville; four great grandchildren, Richard and Charles Brown and Alice and Janet Reich
. The following sisters and brother survive: Mrs. Elizabeth Peters, of Miltonsburg; Mrs. Mary Zerger, of Woodsfield, and Fred W. Hoff, of Alliance, Ohio, also five nieces and four nephews.
  The deceased was a member of the Evangelical and Reformed Church, being baptized and confirmed at an early age. She was also a member of the Senior Womens Union of ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> The deceased was a member of the Evangelical and Reformed Church, being baptized and confirmed at an early age. She was also a member of the Senior Women s Union of >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 the local Church. She led a consistent Christian life and was ready to go when God called her home. She was a kind and loving Mother and was loved and respected by all who knew her. All that could be done was done with kind and willing hands but to no avail; but Mother is in heaven and if we live for our God we shall meet her in her eternal home never more to part.
  Brief funeral services were held at the family home, Monday afternoon at 2:00 oclock, followed by additional services at St. Pauls Evangelical and Reformed Church, ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> Brief funeral services were held at the family home, Monday afternoon at 2:00 o clock, followed by additional services at St. Paul s Evangelical and Reformed Church, >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 with the Reverend R. W. Jungfer, Jr., her pastor officiating. Burial was made in Oaklawn cemetery, Woodsfield.
 
Claus, Mrs. Mary K. (nee Schmidt)
               On Sunday morning, Januaryuary 15, 1905, between 4 and 5 oclock, the angel of called at the home of Justus ======= style='mso-tab-count:1'> On Sunday morning, Januaryuary 15, 1905, between 4 and 5 o clock, the angel of called at the home of Justus >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Claus, near Monroefield, Ohio and tore out of the midst of a loving family the beloved wife and mother, Mrs. Mary K. (Caroline) Claus, nee Schmidt. Having seen ailing for some time, she welcomed as the liberator from all evil, and saw in it a means of being united with her Savior. She was born in Malaga township, Monroe County, Ohio, August 5, 1847. In 1867, on the 7th of February, she was united in the bonds of matrimony with Mr. Justus Claus. This union was blessed with 10 children - - 6 daughters and 4 sons, one of whom preceded his mother into eternity. Her husband, 9 children, 10 grandchildren and one brother mourn her departure. The remains were laid to rest in the Miltonsburg cemetery, Miltonsburg, Ohio on Tuesday, January 17. Funeral services conducted by the Reverend F. A. MEUSCH of Miltonsburg.
Tis hard to break the tender cord,
When love has bound the heart;
Tis hard, so hard, to speak the words,
Must we forever part?
Dearest loved one we have laid thee,
In <<<<<<< HEAD the peaceful graves embrace,
======= the peaceful grave s embrace, >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711
But the memory will be cherished
Till we see thy heavenly face.
Justus <<<<<<< HEAD Claus and children.

  Mr. Claus, a ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> Mr. Claus, a >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 former resident of Woodsfield, died Tuesday morning, August 22, 1950, at the home of his daughter, Mrs. Hickman Merritt in Longview following a Long illness.
  Mr. Claus was born near Monroefield, a son of Charles and Margaret Hoff Claus. He spent most of his life in Monroe County, moving to Pittsburgh several years ago where he was in the insurance business. For the past two years he has resided with his daughters in Texas. He was a member of St. Johns Evangelical and Reformed ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> Mr. Claus was born near Monroefield, a son of Charles and Margaret Hoff Claus. Claus, Stella Amille Schrader
Source--News Clipping
Published--1954
Claus, Stella Amille Schrader, was born on December 24, 1889 and departed this life on June 9, 1954 at the age of 64 years, 5 months and 15 days. She was the daughter of George and Christine Smith Schrader. A life-long resident of Miltonsburg Community, she was baptized and confirmed in Saint Peter's Evangelical Church where she remained a faithful member all her days.
Surviving are her husband, Frank Claus; one daughter, Mrs. Charlene Drake, of the home, and one son, Keith of Canton, Ohio; one granddaughter , Cheryl Drake, and one sister, Mrs. Alma Hinderlong of Miltonsburg. In the immediate family, one daughter, Ruth, preceded her in death on January 14, 1960.
 Of the many ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> Of the many >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 poems written by her daughter, Ruth, here is the one entitled "Mother" which was dedicated to her own mother, although never completed..
                  M  is for the millions of Mothers, who have done so many and magnificant Deeds,
                  O  is for "Opportunity," ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> M is for the millions of Mothers, who have done so many and magnificant Deeds,
O is for "Opportunity," >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 America, the land of opportunity, made so because of the love, sacrifice, and courage of Mothers.
                  T  is for the Threads of our ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> T is for the Threads of our >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 lives, which so many times have been broken, yet put together, and mended by a Mother's hands.
                  H  is for Homes, the bulwark of a nation, made happy because of the work and efforts of our Mothers.
                  E  is for Example- a pattern for us to follow, cut out, and perfected by God as a gift for us.
                  ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> H is for Homes, the bulwark of a nation, made happy because of the work and efforts of our Mothers.
E is for Example- a pattern for us to follow, cut out, and perfected by God as a gift for us.
>>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Funeral services were held Friday, June 11, in St. Peter's Evangelical and Reformed Church in Miltonsburg in charge of Reverend George Varnes. Burial was made in the Miltonsburg Cemetery by the Bauer and Turner Funeral Home.
 
Claus, Virginia and Roscoe Wilhelm
Marriage of Mr. Roscoe Wilhelm and Miss Virginia Claus
Source: The Monroe County Beacon, Woodsfield, Ohio, dated, June 1949
Collection of Gertrude Christman Kahrig
On Saturday evening, June 18, 1949 Reverend Elmer A. Gradwohl read the single ring ceremony at St. Paul's Evangelical and Reformed Church in Woodsfield which united in marriage Miss Virginia Claus, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gilbert Claus of Route 1, Lewisville, Ohio and Mr. Roscoe Wilhelm, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Wilhelm of route 2, Lewisville.
For her wedding, the bride wore a street length dress of pink with white accessories.
The only attendants at the wedding were the bride's parents and sister, Miss Vivian Claus, and Mrs. Gradwohl.
Mr. and Mrs. Wilhelm are residing at the home of the groom's parents on Lewisville, Route 2.
The following day, Sunday, June 19th, a wedding dinner was served at the home of the bride's grandparents, Mr. and Mrs. George L. Christman, on route 1, Lewisville.
This was a double celebration, it also being the forty-ninth wedding anniversary of Mr. and Mrs. Christman. Mrs. Christman is the former Miss Lena Matz. They have always resided in this community.
Guests were: Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Christman, Mr. and Mrs. Carl Buss of Apple Creek; Mr. and Mrs. Gilbert Claus, children, Alvin and Vivian; Mr. and Mrs. Alfred Kahrig, children, Marion, Lena, Lewis and Marlene; Miss Elma Christman; Mr. and Mrs. George Kahrig and children, Wayne, Letha, Viola, Lillian, Meredith, Wilford and Edilene; Mr. and Mrs. Wilbert Claus, son Roger, and the honored guests, Mr. and Mrs. George L. Christman and Mr. and Mrs. Roscoe Wilhelm. Two of the Christman sons were unable to be present.
 
Clauss, Robert G.
May 18, 1919
Feb 5, 1996
Jerusalem

Harlan E. CLEVELAND
Source:The Marietta Times, Marietta, Ohio, January 2, 2003
(Lewisville High School graduate, class of 1940)
  YUKON, Okla. - ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> YUKON, Okla. - >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Harlan E. Cleveland, 81, of Yukon died Saturday (December 28, 2002) after a lengthy illness. He was born October 22, 1921, in Cambridge to Tony and Mary Wehr Waggle Cleveland. His home was later in Marietta for several years and, during this period, he was employed at the Leader Restaurant and later in the restaurant at the Hotel Lafayette.
He enlisted in the U.S. Air Force and retired as a technical sergeant after 29 years. He then began a second career with the U.S. Postal Service in Lubbock, Texas, as a clerk. He was later transferred in 1972 to Kalamazoo, Mich., where he remained until his retirement in 1987. After the of his wife, he visited with his daughter in Oklahoma each winter from October until May when he would return to Kalamazoo. In 1998, he moved to the Mustang/Yukon area of Oklahoma and made visits to all of his children's homes in the area and shared time with his grandchildren. He enjoyed talking with people wherever he went.
 
  During World ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> During World >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 War II, he was in the Marshall and Marianna Island campaigns and the Battle of Okinawa. He also served in both the Korean conflict and the Vietnam War. During his career in the military, he and his wife lived and traveled in many places within the continental United States and also in Alaska, Okinawa, Rhyuku Islands and Japan. He was a member of the American Legion, 4078, Veterans of Foreign Wars, Disabled American Veterans and Free and Accepted Masons. He married Ruth GArnet Delaney of Marietta January 5, 1947. She died November 30, 1987.
  He is survived ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> He is survived >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 by three daughters, Sharon Walls and her husband, Hal, of Yukon, Harla Hale and her husband, Glenn, of Abilene, Texas, and Sara Podwika and her husband, Tom, of Yukon; three sisters, Helen Miller of Zanesville, Bernetta Dotson of Marietta and Nancy Joyce of Iowa, La.; and 11 grandchildren.
 
 
======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711

Cline, A.
            Died: ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> Died: >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 June 17, 1929

Cline, Alice P.
 
Feb 3, 1910
 
June 3, 1992
 
Graysville
 
MARRIAGE, 1913                         
CLINE, Alonzo and HIGHMAN, Miss Edna
    On Saturday morning, January 11, 1913, Mr. Alonzo E. Cline and Miss Edna Arrena Highman accompanied by their brothers Alonzo Highman and Charles Cline, drove over to Woodsfield and secured a marriage permit and were married by "Squire Hoeffler."  After the ceremony was performed they returned to the home of the brides parents, Mr. and Mrs. Abner Highman and where they found about fifty invited guests had assembled for the occasion. After extending congratulations and best wishes and spending a short time in social conversation, we were invited to the dining room where we found a table loaded with all the good things the season afforded to which all did ample justice. The bride, who is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Abner Highman, was dressed in White silk which was very appropriate for the occasion. The groom is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Christian Cline and wore a suit of Brown serge. Mr. and Mrs. Cline are highly respected young people, he being one of Monroe Counties leading school teachers and no doubt did well in choosing her for his life companion. The afternoon was spent in music and conversation then followed the distribution of the presents as follows: Abner Highman $100, Mrs. Abner Highman, set of dishes; Georgia Highman, rocker; Mr.and Mrs. Alta Highman, pitcher and spoon holder; Austin Sloan, dish; Mary Sloan, dish; Della Sloan, dish; Mr. and Mrs. O. E. Highman, tablecloth; Mr and Mrs. A. H. Highman $1; S. M. Highman, bedspread; Guy Edington 50 cents; Charles Cline $1; Clarence Highman, two dishes; D. E. Hartshorn and family , bedspread; James Drake, cake set; Lillian D. Lucas, dish; Olive Cronin, dish; Eska Steed, dish; Mr. and Mrs. D. O. Jones, two dishes & Alonzo Highman, dish. In the evening we returned to our homes feeling that the day was well spent and hoping to be present on many <<<<<<< HEAD such occasions.                                               One who was there
======= such occasions. One who was there >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711
Source:The Spirit of Democracy, Thursday, January 16,1913
 
 
Alonzo Cline
Source:The Monroe County Beacon, Monday, May 15, 1950
 
Alonzo E. Cline, son of Christian and Martha Cline, was born in Monroe County, Ohio, January 3, 1892, and passed to his eternal rest April 6, 1950, being at the time of his 58 years, 3 months, and 3 days. He was united in marriage with Arrena Highman on January 11, 1913, and to this union were born six sons and four daughters, who survive.
 
 He leaves to ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> He leaves to >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 mourn his departure, his wife and the following sons and daughters: Denzil and Hilton Cline of Ashland, Ohio; Mrs. Herbert Shafer, of Ashland, Ohio; Mrs. Ferrel Vanwy, of Newark, Ohio; Mrs. Brady Turner, of Woodsfield, Route one; Robert Cline, of Woodsfield; Herbert, Edison, Kenneth, Miss Wilma Cline, and a little granddaughter, Janet, of the home; three brothers, Charles R. Cline, of Elberton, Georgia; Herman Cline, of Woodsfield, Route 2, and Harley Cline, of Sistersville, W.Va.; two sisters, Mrs. Harry Crawford, of Mt. Pleasant, Michigan, and Mrs. Leland Hogue, of Newark, Ohio; thirteen grandchildren and many other relatives and friends.
 
 He was a member ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> He was a member >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 of The Conner Ridge Methodist Church and was active in church work serving as Superintendent of the Sunday School for many years. Mr. Cline spent his entire life in Wayne Township, engaged in teaching in the public schools of Monroe County and in operating his farm. Since his retirement after thirty-seven years of teaching in the public schools, he had taught G. I. farm school at Graysville, Ohio. Lonnie was an industrious farmer and an Earnest kindly teacher. Hundreds of boys and girls throughout Monroe County stand in sorrow today, feeling keenly the loss of a great teacher and a good friend. Quietly and sincerely he went about his work, implanting the great truths of life upon the minds of young folks that will live on and on. Their lives have been made richer by his having lived.
 
Lonnie was well known and highly respected in our community. Many are the words of encouragement and good advice he has given to his friends and neighbors. He will be sadly missed in our community and in the home. His wife, children and little grandchildren will miss his wise counsel and his gentle hand. We, who are left, shall not question the infinite wisdom of Almighty God. We shall try, to so order our lives, that we may meet our husband and father in a brighter world than this, where sickness and heartaches are unknown.
 
Funeral services were held Sunday afternoon at two o'clock at The Conner Ridge Methodist Church, with Rev. E. Merle Long, officiating. Burial was in Oaklawn Cemetery at Woodsfield, with The Gardner Funeral Home of Stafford in charge.
 
Cline, Andrew
February 19, 1923

Cline, Effie Blanche (nee Barrett)
Mrs. Effie Blanche Cline, 67, of Quaker City Route 4 died at 5:45 pm
Monday (October 11) in Barnesville Hospital.
Mrs. Cline was born in Warren Township October 8, 1898, a daughter of John
F. and Rachel Payne Barrett. She was a member of Bethel Methodist Church on
Leatherwood road near Barnesville.
Surviving are her husband, Willis Cline of the home; a daughter Mrs.
Ruth Robinson of Cambridge, three grandchildren; five brothers, F. L.
Barrett of Newark, George, Clyde and Charles all of Barnesville, and Ray of
Quaker City; two sisters, Mrs. Mary Gibson of Newark, and Mrs. Isabelle
Pfalzgraf of Lewisville. A daughter Mary died in 1948 and a brother Ross
Barrett, died in 1956.
The body is at Campbell Funeral Home in Barnesville where friends may
call after 1 pm (EST) Wednesday. Services will be held at 1 pm (EST)
Thursday at the funeral home with Rev. Milford Carey officiating. Burial
will be at Friends Cemetery Quaker City.
[Source:The Times Recorder, Zanesville, Ohio, Tuesday, October 12, 1956, p.
2A] Provided by Becky Graham Stephenson

Cline, Florence Cline
November 19, 1916
Florence Cline [Source:The Spirit of Democracy Woodsfield, Ohio, Thurs., November 23, 1916]
  Miss Florence ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> Miss Florence >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Cline, 23, and resident of Jolly, Monroe County, Ohio, drank strychnine after she returned home Sunday night from a young peoples meeting at the M. E. Church in the village and died shortly before midnight.
 
  No motive ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> No motive >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 could be leArned. Members of the family say she was in good health and spirits. During the day she sang and played the piano at her home. Going to the Church in the evening she sang in the choir and in her demeanor there was nothing to indicate that she contemplated suicide. Returning home with other members of the family the young lady remained downstairs reading after the others had <<<<<<< HEAD retired. About eleven oclock she went to her mothers bed and remarked, I feel queer. Asked what the trouble was she is said to have answered, I took strychnine, A Bottle containing the poison had been left in a downstairs cupboard. Do something for me or Ill die, she is said to have urged. F. E. ======= retired. About eleven o clock she went to her mother s bed and remarked, I feel queer. Asked what the trouble was she is said to have answered, I took strychnine, A Bottle containing the poison had been left in a downstairs cupboard. Do something for me or I ll die, she is said to have urged. F. E. >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Cline, father of the girl, hurried for Dr. Edwards.
Two minutes after he arrived at the home the young lady expired. The father is a stoneMason and carpenter. The dead girl is survived by three sisters and four brothers. Funeral services will be held Thursday afternoon. Miss Cline formerly worked here in town and was well liked by everybody who knew her.

  Cline ,George ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'>Published-- May 1969
Cline ,George >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 W. ,62, of Lewisville, supervisor of case workers for Aid to the Aged in Monroe County, died at 8:30 p.m. Friday (May 22) at his home following several months illness.
  He was born December 8, 1907, in Jericho, a son of John and Myrtle SteWard Cline.
  Mr. Cline was ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> He was born December 8, 1907, in Jericho, a son of John and Myrtle SteWard Cline.
Mr. Cline was >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 a member of Buchanan Presbyterian Church, Masonic Lodge F&AM of Stafford, and Lewisville Volunteer Fire Department.
  He leaves his ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> He leaves his >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 widow, Vivian Young Cline; a son, Myron Cline of Burgoon; two grandchildren; two brothers, Miles D. ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711
2002
Monday, May 27, 2002, Marietta Times
Gladys M. Cox, nee Cline
WOODSFIELD - Gladys M. Cox, 97, of 39887 Stonehouse Road died at 7:40 a.m. Sunday (May 26, 2002) at the Monroe County Care Center in Woodsfield.
She was born July 18, 1904, near Antioch to William H. and Anna Payne Cline. She was a graduate of Muskingum College at New Concord. She retired as a school teacher, having taught in various schools throughout Monroe County. She was a member of Plainview Church of Christ near Woodsfield, the Ohio Retired Teachers Association and the Monroe County Retired Teachers Association. She was a 50-year member of the Graysville Grange.
She is survived by three daughters, Mrs. Arnold (Helen) Miracle of Jeromesville, Ohio, Mrs. Dale (Jean) Morris of Woodsfield and Mrs. Daniel (Janet) Belford of Massillon; one brother, Doyle Cline of Seville, Ohio; eight grandchildren; and 16 great-grandchildren.
She was preceded in death by her husband, Willis E. Cox, on Nov. 15, 1969; one son, Robert D. Cox, on July 5, 1998; her parents; five brothers, Orville, Boyd, Bernie, Wilford and Harold Cline; and one grandson, Bruce E. Miracle.
Services are at 11 a.m. Wednesday at Watters Funeral Home in Woodsfield with Harold Kinney Jr. officiating. Burial is in Antioch Cemetery in Antioch, Ohio. Friends will be received from 2 to 4 and 7 to 9 p.m. Tuesday at the funeral home.

Cline, James W. Cline
Died: October 5, 1917
 
Cline, james.
Published-Times Recorder, Zanesville,Ohio
October 25, 1944
            Cline, ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> Cline, >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 James : James Cline, 66, well known Woodsfield man, passed away very suddenly Monday evening October 23 1944 at his residence, on Sycamore St. He had been ill for the past three weeks with a heart ailment but it was thought he was recovering. His death was a shock to relatives and friends. He is survived by his wife, three sons, Harold Cline, twin sons, Herbert and HoWard, all who are serving with the U. S. armed forces. There are three grandchildren. For a number of years Mr. Cline was associated with the W. H. Jackson store, where he made many friends. A member of the Presbyterian Church. Was interested and active in all church affairs. The body was taken to the Bauer & Turner Funeral Home. Arrangements are incomplete pending the arrival of the sons.
Provided by Lena kahrig Pettit, typed by Betty Lendon Matson

Cline, Joy Watters

November 3, 1988

CERTIFICATION

Joy Watters

Source: Monroe County Beacon

 

     Joy Watters has earned her ======= JA'> Joy Watters has earned her >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 certificate of registration from the State of Ohio Board of Embalmers and Funeral Directors. She is now serving an apprenticeship under direction of her husband, Bruce Watters.

     The certification follows ======= JA'> The certification follows >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 completion of 90-quarter hours of studies at Ohio University Belmont. When the two-year apprenticeship is accomplished, Joy will take the state board testing to become a funeral director.

     She comments, "We are ======= JA'> She comments, "We are >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 seeing a trend of wives joining husbands in this field of business. Bruce and I feel my becoming a licensed director will certainly enhance our business and enable us to better serve our tow locations."

     Watters Funeral Homes are ======= JA'> Watters Funeral Homes are >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 located in Woodsfield and Summerfield.

     Joy, a 1976 graduate of Skyvue ======= JA'> Joy, a 1976 graduate of Skyvue >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 High School, is the daughter of Kenneth D. and Rosalie Cline.

 
Cline, Kathryn L. Cline nee Keyser
Source:The Marietta Times, Marietta, OH, dated Friday, March 12, 2004
 
Woodsfield - Kathryn L. Cline, 94, of North Main Street died Thursday (March 11, 2004) at the Woodsfield Nursing and Rehabilitation Center. She was born July 19, 1909, in Woodsfield to John Keyser and Emma Tschappat Keyser. She was a retired Woodsfield Elementary School teacher with 40 years of service.
 
She was a member of Woodsfield Presbyterian Church, a past worthy matron and member of the Eastern Star Lodge of Woodsfield, and a member of the American Legion Auxiliary.
 
She was preceded in by her husband, Harold G. Cline, in 1980; one daughter, Alice Porter, in 1997; two brothers, Phillip and Calvin Keyser; and two sisters, Clara Ward and Florence Spriggs.
 
She is survived by one son, James Cline and his wife, Mary V., of Woodsfield; five grandchildren, Rod Cline, Alan Cline, Jon Porter Jr., Jeffrey Porter and Christopher Porter; and six great-grandchildren.
 
Graveside services are at 2 p.m. Sunday at Oaklawn Cemetery in Woodsfield with Pastor Connie Garlick officiating. There is no visitation. Bauer-Turner Funeral Home at 100 S. Paul St., Woodsfield, is in charge of arrangements.
Memorial contributions may be made to the Presbyterian Church Memorial Fund, 100 Cherry St., Woodsfield, Ohio 43793.

Kenneth Dale Cline
 
Source:The Marietta Times, dated Tuesday, January 27, 2004
 
Woodsfield - Kenneth D. Cline, 67, of 38000 Wolf Pen Road died at 6:05 p.m. Sunday (January 25, 2004) at the Woodsfield Nursing and Rehabilitation Center in Woodsfield. He was born February 10, 1936, near Woodsfield to Alonzo Elmer "Lonnie" and Edna Arrena Highman Cline. He was a retired heavy equipment operator for Ohio Operating Engineers Local 18, Akron, <<<<<<< HEAD where he was also a lifetime member.  He ======= where he was also a lifetime member. He >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 was a member of the Graysville Church of Christ in Graysville. He was a
former Wayne Township trustee in Monroe County.
 
He is survived by his wife, Rosalie J. Paden Cline; three daughters, Mrs. Daniel (Lisa) Robertson of Lewisville, Mrs. Bruce (Joy) Watters of Woodsfield and Mrs. Thomas (Januaryice) Lemon of Holmesville, Ohio; four sisters, Mrs. Herbert (Grethel) Shafer of Ashland, Ohio, Mrs. Roy (Dorothy "Dot") Fink of Newark, Jean Ambrus of Newark and Wilma Babcock of Frazeysburg, Ohio; one brother, Hilton "Pete" Cline and his wife, Evelyn, of Polk, Ohio; and five grandchildren, Lucas D. Robertson, Craig A. Robertson, Kara N. Watters, Kendra J. Lemon and Kenton D. Lemon.
 
He was preceded in by his parents; and four brothers, Denzil Cline, Robert Cline, Herbert Cline and Eddie Cline.
 
Services are at 1 p.m. Friday at Watters Funeral Home in Woodsfield with Harold Kinney Jr. and Sam Bartrug officiating. Burial is in Oaklawn Cemetery in Woodsfield. Friends will be received from 2 to 4 and 7 to 9 p.m. Thursday at the funeral home.

Cline, Linda Lea and Stanley R. Novemberak
Source--The Monroe County Beacon
Published--August 12, 1972
 Provided by Lena Kahrig Pettit, typed by Betty Lendon Matson
  St. Paul's ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> Provided by Lena Kahrig Pettit, typed by Betty Lendon Matson
St. Paul's >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 United Church of Christ, Woodsfield, was the setting Saturday, August twelfth, at half after two o'clock in the afternoon, for the marriage of Miss Linda Lea Cline, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederic Cline, 226 Eastern Avenue, Woodsfield, and Mr. and Mrs. James Thomas Novemberak, son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley R. Novemberak, 23416 Royalton Road, Columbia Station, Ohio. The Rev. Charles Price officiated at the double ring, open church ceremony. Mrs. Nile Kamp provided the nuptial music.
  Given in ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> Given in >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 marriage by her father, the bride appeared in a Suzanne original gown of pure
silk organza and Venice lace with molded bodice and bishop sleeves. The neckline and wide waistline were banded with embroidered organza. The full gored skirt was floor-length and was sprinkled with Venice lace appliques, cascading into a full sweep. Her imported pure silk illusion cathedral veil was held in place with a Venice lace cloche. She carried a cascade bouquet of yellow and white daisy pomps, sprinkled with baby's breath, and ending in long yellow streamers.
  Maid of honor was Miss Kathy Elekes, of Zanesville, friend of the bride, and bridesmaid was Miss Valerie Touvelle, of Columbus, cousin of the bride.  James Wycoff, of Athens, served Mr. ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> Maid of honor was Miss Kathy Elekes, of Zanesville, friend of the bride, and bridesmaid was Miss Valerie Touvelle, of Columbus, cousin of the bride. James Wycoff, of Athens, served Mr. >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Novemberak as best man. Usher was Mr. Mark Novemberak, of Columbia Station, brother of the bridegroom. Ring bearer for her sister was Stacy Cline.
  The ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> The >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 bridesmaids appeared in adentical gowns of mimosa French voille, featuring a high rise waistline, and molded bodice with wide V ruffle in front and back.The high neckline with ruffle and bodice and long sleeves were banded in mimosa and white daisy braid, ending in a tailored bow with streamers at the back. Their skirts were A-line featuring fullness at the back and worn in a sweep. They carried cascade bouquets of white and yellow daisy pomps and white streamers.
  A reception followed at The Switzerland of Ohio Country Club.
  Mrs. ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> A reception followed at The Switzerland of Ohio Country Club.
Mrs. >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Novemberak, a Woodsfield High School graduate, received her Bachelor of Science Degree in Education from Ohio University. She is a mamber of Phi Mu social sorority.
  Her husband, a ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> Her husband, a >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 graduate of Columbia High School and Ohio University with a Bachelor of Science degree in Education, is a member of Phi Kappa Sigma social fraternity. He is serving with The United States Army at Fort Meade, Maryland.
  The couple ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> The couple >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 will reside at 8813 Hawthorne Court, Apt. 101, Briarwood Apts., Laurel, Maryland, after a wedding trip to Seven Springs, Pennsylvania.

Cline, Pauline Knowlton

March 1988

Pauline Knowlton,nee Cline

     Pauline Knowlton age 58, of Graysville, Ohio died early Monday morning March 7, 1988 at the Barnesville Hospital.  She was born December 1, 1929 ======= JA'> Pauline Knowlton age 58, of Graysville, Ohio died early Monday morning March 7, 1988 at the Barnesville Hospital. She was born December 1, 1929 >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 in Monroe County, Ohio the daughter of Delbert and Ruby Haught Cline of New Matamoras Route 1, Ohio.

     She was preceded in death by her husband Raymond Knowlton in 1970.  She is survived by 4 daughters: Mrs. Eric (Debbie) Highman  Woodsfield; Mrs. Dwaine (Sally) Craig  Lewisville; Mrs. Jack (Patty) Turner  Graysville; and Denise Knowlton  Graysville, 9 grandchildren and 1 sister  Mrs. Clyde (Yvonne) Weckbacher  Rinard Mills.

     Friends were received at the Bauer-Turner Funeral Home Woodsfield Tuesday March 8, 1988, where services were held Wednesday March 9, 1988 with Rick Tincher and Don Thompson officiating.  Interment was in the Low Gap Cemetery, New Matamoras R#1, Ohio.  ======= JA'> She was preceded in death by her husband Raymond Knowlton in 1970. She is survived by 4 daughters: Mrs. Eric (Debbie) Highman Woodsfield; Mrs. Dwaine (Sally) Craig Lewisville; Mrs. Jack (Patty) Turner Graysville; and Denise Knowlton Graysville, 9 grandchildren and 1 sister Mrs. Clyde (Yvonne) Weckbacher Rinard Mills.

Friends were received at the Bauer-Turner Funeral Home Woodsfield Tuesday March 8, 1988, where services were held Wednesday March 9, 1988 with Rick Tincher and Don Thompson officiating. Interment was in the Low Gap Cemetery, New Matamoras R#1, Ohio. >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Family requests contributions be made to the Monroe County Cancer Society and the National Arthritis Foundation.

Cline, Shelda (nee Hill)
            Reynoldsburg, ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> Reynoldsburg, >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Ohio - We celebrate the passing of our beloved mother, grandmother and aunt, Shelda Hill Cline. Shelda made her way back home to be with her Lord and Savior on Wednesday (Sept. 15, 2004).
            She ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> She >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 was born Aug. 27, 1913, in New Matamoras, Ohio, one of five children of Herman and Nettie Kochert Hill.
She was predeceased by her parents; her husband, Howard L. Cline; her brothers, Wayne Hill and James "Bill" Hill; her daughter, Marsha Jean Cline; and her sister, Dorothy Parker.
 
Shelda attended Marietta College and spent most of her life in New Matamoras and Marietta before moving to Venice, Fla., in 1985. Shelda has lived in Reynoldsburg, Ohio, since 1992 with her daughter, Carmel (Dennis) Jenkins.
            She ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> She >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 leaves behind a devoted grandson, Jay Jenkins, and his fiance, Chessa; her sister, Opal Yonally; and several nieces and nephews.
            Graveside ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> Graveside >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 services will be held on Sunday (Sept. 19) in New Matamoras. Her arrangements are being cared for by the Cotner Funeral Home in Reynoldsburg.
Source: The Marietta Times, Friday, September 17, 2004
 
Cline, Robert Woodrow
            Woodsfield, ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> Woodsfield, >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Ohio- Robert Woodrow Cline, 83, of Woodsfield, died Friday Sept. 22, 2000 at the Monroe County Care Center, Woodsfield.
He was born Dec. 12, 1916, near Woodsfield, son of the late Alonzo E. and Arrena E. (Highman) Cline.
Mr. Cline was a retired farmer and a member of the Conner Ridge United Methodist Church, near Woodsfield.
He was a U.S. Army veteran, having served in World War II. During his service in the military he received two Bronze Stars a Purple Heart and was a prisoner of war
He was a life member of the VFW Post 5303, Woodsfield.
He was preceded in death by three brothers, Herbert, Denzil and Eddie Cline.
He leaves his wife, Jean E. (Turner) Cline, whom he married June 10, 1940;
four sisters, Mrs. Herb (Grethel) Shafer of Ashland, Wilma Babcock of
Frazeysburg, Jean Ambrus and Mrs. Roy (Dorothy) Fink, both of Newark;
two brothers, Kenneth D. (Rosalie) Cline of Woodsfield and Hilton (Evelyn) Cline of Polk; several nieces and nephews.
Friends may call from 2 to 9 p.m. today at Watters Funeral Home, Woodsfield, where services will be 1 p.m. Monday, with Harold B. Kinney Jr. officiating. Burial will be in Oaklawn Cemetery, Woodsfield.
Military graveside services will be conducted by Belmont Veterans Council
Source:  Monroe ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'>Source: Monroe >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 County Beacon dated September 28, 2000

Source:Marietta Times . . Marietta, OH . . Aug 2001
Provided by Betty Lendon Matson
            LORAIN ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> LORAIN >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 -- Zelda Cline, 89, of Lorain died Sunday (August 19, 2001) at New Life Hospice Center of St. Joseph in Lorain after a lengthy illness.
She was born Octoberober 11, 1911, in Monroe County to Evan and Gracie Durbin. She moved to Lorain from Monroe County in 1941, and to Vermilion in 1946.
            She ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> She >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 was a member of Brownhelm Congregational Church in Brownhelm. She worked during World War II at Thew-Shovel in Lorain and South Shore Packing Co. in Vermilion. Her hobbies included gardening, canning and Cooking.
            She ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> She >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 is survived by two daughters, Kathern Beursken and Marjorie Gassnig, both of Vermilion; three sons, Lewis Melvin Cline of Chula Vista, Calif., Cecil Charles Cline of Williams, Ore., and Clayton Eldred Cline of Vermilion; 16 grandchildren; and many great-grandchildren.
            She ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> She >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 was preceded in death by her husband, Lawrence F. Cline, on February 15, 1996; three sisters, Mary Scott, Flossie Scott and Mabel Widener; and four brothers, Charlie, Arland, Orlando "Jake," and James Durbin.
            Services ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> Services >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 are at 10 a.m. Wednesday at Riddle Funeral Home, 5345 South St., Vermilion, with the Rev. Stephanie Bikel, pastor of Brownhelm Congregational United Church of Christ, officiating. Burial is in Rugby Cemetery in Brownhelm Township. The family will receive friends from 2 to 4 and 7 to 9 p.m. Tuesday at the funeral home.
